Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Dynamics of complex quantum systems, scaling limits and renormalization
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project addresses three main topics:
(1) The well-posedness theory of the initial value problem for the Gross-Pitaevskii (GP) hierarchy,
based on the approach initiated by the PI jointly with N. Pavlovic (UT Austin).
A main motivation underlying our work is our aim at generalizing methods from nonlinear dispersive
PDE's for the analysis of quantum field theories (QFT's).
(2) Problems in non-relativistic Quantum Electrodynamics (QED), in particular relating to the
semiclassical motion of electrons, radiation damping, and the problem of ultraviolet
renormalization in QED.
(3) Derivation of kinetic equations from kinetic scaling limits of the thermal momentum
distribution function for interacting electron gases, modeled in dynamical Hartree-Fock theory.
These projects involve several ongoing collaborations, including international ones.

Study of the GP hierarchy, which emerges in the analysis of interacting Bose gases, bridges
some of the most exciting recent developments in physics (Bose-Einstein condensation)
with some of the most impressive recent developments in mathematics (nonlinear dispersive PDE's).
Non-relativistic QED is the physical theory of non-relativistic quantum mechanical matter
(electrons, atoms, molecules) interacting with the energy quanta (photons) of light, and
describes processes in a wide spectrum of quintessential areas in technology (chemistry,
electronics, modeling of solar panels, etc). The derivation of kinetic equations from quantum
dynamics leads to a precise mathematical understanding of classical physics (fluid dynamics)
from quantum physics.
The educational component of this project involves the training of graduate students in highly multidisciplinary
annual thematic programs that provide them with a integrative and specialized understanding of
links between Analysis, Applied and Computational Mathematics, nonlinear PDE's, and Mathematical Physics.
The goal is to provide graduate students with an exceptionally broad understanding of their research fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The projects supported by this NSF CAREER Award focus on the mathematically rigorous analysis of the dynamics of quantum mechanical matter. In addition, this grant has supported Graduate Minicourses introducing graduate and advanced undergraduate students to research areas in the intersection of Quantum Mechanics, Quantum Field Theory, Analysis, Partial Differential Equations, and Probability.

 

If a gas of Bose particles is cooled to sufficiently low temperatures, Bose-Einstein condensation can occur. This is the phenomenon in which all (or an overwhelmingly large fraction) of the bosonic particles exhibit the exactly same quantum mechanical behavior. Thereby, a Bose-Einstein condensate is macroscopically observable matter in a quantum mechanical state. A main line of research supported by this grant addresses the emergence of the nonlinear Schrodinger and Hartree equations as the effective description of dilute Bose-Einstein condensates. Key results obtained include the derivation and analysis of those equations with methods bridging methods of Quantum Field Theory with modern techniques of nonlinear dispersive partial differential equations (PDEs). In particular, the problem of proving uniqueness of solutions is solved in an entirely new way, using the quantum de Finetti theorem. These projects were collaborations with N. Pavlovic, and partially with C. Hainzl, R. Seiringer, K. Taliaferro, and N. Tzirakis. In a very recently collaboration with A. Soffer, the dynamics of a heavy tracer particle inside a Bose-Einstein condensate is derived using a combination of Fock space and dispersive PDE methods.

 

The fluctuation dynamics around a Bose-Einstein condensate (that is, the behavior of particles that do not belong to the condensate) is analyzed in the quasifree approximation, yielding the Hartree-Fock-Bogoliubov equations. This is a self-consistent approximative description of the system in which all correlations between particles can be expressed in terms of one- and two-particle correlations. This is an ongoing collaboration with V. Bach, S. Breteaux. J. Frohlich, and I.M. Sigal.

 

The behavior of a Fermi gas is entirely different; the Pauli principle asserts that no two fermions can be in the same quantum mechanical state. In collaboration with N. Pavlovic and Y. Hong, methods of dispersive nonlinear PDEs are extended to the density matrix formalism, in order to describe the fluctuation dynamics of a fermion field near thermal equilibrium. 

 

In collaboration with R. Denlinger and N. Pavlovic, we analyze the Boltzmann equation by transforming it into an equation of a similar form as those appearing in the above projects. This is achieved with application of the Wigner transform. The purpose is to explore the use of tools of dispersive nonlinear PDEs, in order to gain better understanding of the Boltzmann equation from a new perspective.

 

With T. Komorowski and L. Ryzhik, we studied the average dynamics of an electron in a random medium with slowly decaying correlations in various scaling regimes.

 

With W. Abou Salem and V. Vougalter, we analyzed the semi-relativistic Schrodinger-Poisson system which describes a heated plasma in which particles are moving with extremely high velocities. 

 

On the educational level, this grant has supported the organization of Graduate Minicourses: Leading experts were invited to present a survey talk aimed at graduate students and advanced undergraduate students introducing them to key notions, questions, and motivations in their research areas. Subsequently, an in-depth research talk about recent results in those topics was presented after this preparation. Researchers presenting such courses included I. Corwin, J. Colliander, C. Hainzl,  V. Hoang, J. Holmer, Y. Hong, D. Hundertmark, J.O. Lee, A. Nahmod, I. Nenciu, R. Seiringer, I.M. Sigal, G. Simpson, V. Sohinger, C. Sparber, N. Tzirakis, G. Zhou. Topics included well-posedness theory of nonlinear Schrodinger equations, Gross-Pitaevskii hierarchies, Euler equations, and Boltzmann equations, dynamics of Bose and Fermi gases, BCS theory,  KPZ universality, spectral problems, among others.
